answers.answer: Since you've lived with diabetes for 18 years, you know how challenging it can be to manage blood sugars on a daily basis.  The importance of tight control cannot be overemphasized when it comes to pregnancy.  Elevated glucose does reduce your chances for conceiving.  At the time of conception (and during the first trimester), elevated glucose can cause significant defects and may lead to spontaneous abortion.  During the 2nd and 3rd trimesters, elevated glucose leads to excessive growth and contributes to premature birth, difficult labor, newborn hypoglycemia and malformations.The bottom line:  You should get your A1c down close to normal BEFORE trying to conceive.  If your current healthcare team is not able to help you, feel free to contact my practice (Integrated Diabetes Services).  We work with women planning to conceive all over the world via phone and the internet.

question: Hi.. I am 25yrs old and have had type 1 diabetes since age 7.. My hba1c is around 8 and lowering slowly.. My partner and i have been trying for a baby for around 6 months now and would just like to know if anyone has any tips for a diabetic that's trying? Any medication to try? I know my hba1c is high, but i am trying very hard to get it lower, but i didn't think diabetes stopped someone from getting pregnant?Any tips would be great thanks! :)
title: diabetic trying to get pregnant
